messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 54 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Adapting the Directed Grid Theorem into an FPT AlgorithmWork supported by projects CAPES/STIC-AmSud 88881.197438/2018-01, CNPq - Universal project 425297/2016-0, FUNCAP - PRONEM PNE-011200061.01.00/16, DEMOGRAPH (ANR-16-CE40-0028), ESIGMA (ANR-17-CE23-0010), ELIT (ANR-20-CE48-0008-01), and UTMA (ANR-20-CE92-0027). An extended abstract of this paper appeared in the Proc. of the X Latin and American Algorithms, Graphs and Optimization Symposium (LAGOS), volume 346 of ENTCS, pages 229‚Äì240, Belo Horizonte, Brazil, June 2019.

Paper Abstract: Abstract The Grid Theorem of Robertson and Seymour [JCTB, 1986] is one of the most important tools in the field of structural graph theory, finding numerous applications in the design of algorithms for undirected graphs. An analogous version of the Grid Theorem in digraphs was conjectured by Johnson et al. [JCTB, 2001], and proved by Kawarabayashi and Kreutzer [STOC, 2015]. Namely, they showed that there is a function f‚Äã(k)ùëìùëòf(k) such that every digraph of directed tree-width at least f‚Äã(k)ùëìùëòf(k) contains a cylindrical grid of order kùëòk as a butterfly minor, and stated that their proof can be turned into an XP algorithm, with parameter kùëòk, that either constructs a decomposition of the appropriate width, or finds the claimed large cylindrical grid as a butterfly minor. In this paper, we adapt some of the steps of the proof of Kawarabayashi and Kreutzer to improve this XP algorithm into an FPT algorithm. Towards this, our main technical contributions are two FPT algorithms with parameter kùëòk. The first one either produces an arboreal decomposition of width 3‚Äãk‚àí23ùëò23k-2 or finds a haven of order kùëòk in a digraph Dùê∑D, improving on the original result for arboreal decompositions by Johnson et al. [JCTB, 2001]. The second algorithm finds a well-linked set of order kùëòk in a digraph Dùê∑D of large directed tree-width. As tools to prove these results, we show how to solve a generalized version of the problem of finding balanced separators for a given set of vertices TùëáT in FPT time with parameter |T|ùëá|T|, a result that we consider to be of its own interest. Keywords: Digraph, directed tree-width, grid theorem, FPT algorithm.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 54 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 54"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "The Erdos-Posa Property for Directed Graphs",
        "Complexity of finding embeddings in a kùëòk-tree",
        "Classes of Directed Graphs",
        "Exponential polynomials",
        "Towards a Polynomial Kernel for Directed Feedback Vertex Set",
        "Nonserial Dynamic Programming",
        "Finding detours is fixed-parameter tractable",
        "Treewidth: characterizations, applications, and computations",
        "On directed feedback vertex set parameterized by treewidth",
        "Graph Theory",
        "Multicut is FPT",
        "On the analytical forms called trees. Second part, volume 4 of Cambridge Library Collection - Mathematics, page 112‚Äì115",
        "Polynomial bounds for the grid-minor theorem",
        "Constant congestion routing of symmetric demands in planar directed graphs",
        "A fixed-parameter algorithm for the directed feedback vertex set problem",
        "Towards Tight(er) Bounds for the Excluded Grid Theorem",
        "Tour merging via branch-decompositions",
        "The monadic second-order logic of graphs. I. Recognizable sets of finite graphs",
        "Parameterized Algorithms",
        "The Planar Directed kùëòk-Vertex-Disjoint Paths Problem is Fixed-Parameter Tractable",
        "An algorithmic metatheorem for directed treewidth",
        "Subexponential parameterized algorithms on bounded-genus graphs and HùêªH-minor-free graphs",
        "Beyond bidimensionality: Parameterized subexponential algorithms on directed graphs",
        "Fundamentals of Parameterized Complexity",
        "Half-integral linkages in highly connected directed graphs",
        "Directed multicut with linearly ordered terminals",
        "Parameterized Complexity Theory",
        "Bidimensionality",
        "The directed subgraph homeomorphism problem",
        "Digraph width measures in parameterized algorithmics",
        "The Directed Flat Wall Theorem",
        "Finding topological subgraphs is fixed-parameter tractable",
        "SùëÜS-functions for graphs",
        "Polynomial Planar Directed Grid Theorem",
        "Directed tree-width",
        "Excluding a grid minor in planar digraphs",
        "An Excluded Grid Theorem for Digraphs with Forbidden Minors",
        "The Directed Grid Theorem",
        "Decision algorithms for unsplittable flow and the half-disjoint paths problem",
        "Solving frequency assignment problems via tree-decomposition",
        "Fixed-parameter tractability of multicut in directed acyclic graphs",
        "Digraph decompositions and monotonicity in digraph searching",
        "A relaxation of the Directed Disjoint Paths problem: a global congestion metric helps",
        "Fixed-parameter tractability of multicut parameterized by the size of the cutset",
        "Quantitative Graph Theory: Mathematical Foundations and Applications",
        "Zur allgemeinen kurventheorie",
        "Directed Multicut is W[1]-hard, Even for Four Terminal Pairs",
        "Introducing directed tree-width",
        "Graph minors. V. Excluding a planar graph",
        "Graph minors. XIII. The disjoint paths problem",
        "Graph minors. XXI. Graphs with unique linkages",
        "Graph Minors. XXII. Irrelevant vertices in linkage problems",
        "Graph searching and a min-max theorem for tree-width",
        "Parameterized tractability of edge-disjoint paths on directed acyclic graphs"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 54 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Adapting the Directed Grid Theorem into an FPT AlgorithmWork supported by projects CAPES/STIC-AmSud 88881.197438/2018-01, CNPq - Universal project 425297/2016-0, FUNCAP - PRONEM PNE-011200061.01.00/16, DEMOGRAPH (ANR-16-CE40-0028), ESIGMA (ANR-17-CE23-0010), ELIT (ANR-20-CE48-0008-01), and UTMA (ANR-20-CE92-0027). An extended abstract of this paper appeared in the Proc. of the X Latin and American Algorithms, Graphs and Optimization Symposium (LAGOS), volume 346 of ENTCS, pages 229‚Äì240, Belo Horizonte, Brazil, June 2019., providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
